de.esoco.lib.collection

Class ByteArray

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.collection.ByteArray
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    de.esoco.lib.json.JsonSerializable<ByteArray>

    public class ByteArray
extends java.lang.Object
implements de.esoco.lib.json.JsonSerializable<ByteArray>
    A dynamic array of bytes that can grow and shrink to hold an arbitrary number of byte values. It also can be converted to and from a JSON string which will have the prefix "0x" followed by a joined sequence of two-char hexadecimal values for each byte. If the byte array is empty, the JSON value is only "0x".

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all entries from the array. The array's size will be 0 afterwards, it's capacity will not be changed.

      • copyTo

        public byte[] copyTo(byte[] rTarget,
                     int nOffset)
        Copies the contents of this array to an simple byte array. The destination array must have a length of at least getSize() + nOffset, otherwise an IndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        rTarget - The target array to copy the array data into
        nOffset - The start position in the destination array
        Returns:
        The target array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the destination array is to small

        public int indexOf(byte nValue,
                   int nPos)
        Searches for a specific value and returns the position of it's first occurence in the array from a certain position.

        Returns:

      • insert

        public void insert(byte nValue,
                   int nIndex)
        Inserts an byte value at an arbitrary position of the array. All values at and behind this position will be shifted one position to the end of the array. If the array capacity is exceeded the array will be resized.
        Parameters:
        nValue - The value to add
        nIndex - The index of the position where the value shall be inserted
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index value is invalid

      • insertAscending

        public int insertAscending(byte nValue,
                           int nStart)
        Inserts a value into the array at a position corresponding to it's ascending numerical order. All values that are greater than the new value will be shifted one position to the end of the array. If the current array capacity is not sufficient the array will be resized.

        If the parameter nStart is greater than 0, the values at the array positions before nStart will be ignored by the insertion. This allows to keep a set of unordered values at the beginning of the array.

        Parameters:
        nValue - The value to insert into the array
        nStart - The position to start comparing values
        Returns:
        The position at which the new value has been inserted

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Checks whether this array is empty.
        Returns:
        TRUE if empty

      • last

        public byte last()
        Returns the last byte value (stored at size -1) in the array.
        Returns:
        The byte value stored at the end of the array

        public byte pop()
        Returns the last byte value and removes it from the array.
        Returns:
        The last byte value in the array
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the array is empty

        public void push(byte nValue)
        Adds an byte value to the end of the array (stack version, calls add()).
        Parameters:

      • remove

        public void remove(int nIndex)
        Removes a value from a certain index position in the array. All values behind that index will be shifted one position to the beginning of the array.
        Parameters:
        nIndex - The position at which a value shall be removed
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index value is invalid

      • setCapacityIncrement

        public void setCapacityIncrement(int nIncrement)
        Sets the amount by which the array capacity will be incremented when the size exceeds the current capacity.
        Parameters:
        nIncrement - The capacity increment

      • setSize

        public void setSize(int nNewSize)
        Sets the size, i.e. the number of byte values that the array contains. If the new size is greater than the current size, new bytes with the value 0 will be added to the end of the array. If the new size extends the current array capacity the capacity will be increased accordingly.
        Parameters:
        nNewSize - The new number of byte values in the array

      • toByteArray

        public byte[] toByteArray()
        Copies the bytes of this array into a byte array. The length of the new array will be exactly the same as the current size (not the capacity) of the ByteArray.
        Returns:
        A new byte array containing all elements of this array

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this array with two hexadecimal digits for each byte without gaps between bytes. For example, a three-byte array with the values 127, 0, 32 would be returned as "7F0020".
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A hexadecimal string representation

      • trimToSize

        public void trimToSize()
        Shrinks the array capacity to it's current size.

        protected final void checkCapacity(int nIncrement)
        Lets the array capacity grow for at least a certain size increment.
        Parameters:
        nIncrement - The minimum increment for which the capacity shall grow

        Checks if a certain index position is valid for the current array size.
        Parameters:
        nIndex - The index value to check
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the given index value is not valid for the current array size

      • setCapacity

        protected final void setCapacity(int nNewCapacity)
        Resizes the array to a certain capacity. The new capacity must always be greater or equal to the current array size.
        Parameters:
        nNewCapacity - The new array capacity
